sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten letter from Harden to Schenker, dated November 24, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden encourages Schenker to write articles on the string quartet and on [Johann] Strauß and Humperdinck, but not on Brahms. —He explains why he lost his temper with Schenker in an earlier letter (see OJ 11/42, [19]). —He urges Schenker to procure some correspondence between Rosenthal and Rubinstein for publication in Die Zukunft; and he casts aspersion on Die Zeit.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Harden, Maximilian; Schenker, Heinrich; Strauss, Johann; Offenbach, Jacques; Brahms; Humperdinck, Engelbert; Rosenthal, Moriz; Rubinstein, Anton; Die Zeit; Neue Freie Presse

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Harden to Schenker, dated November 24, 1894

tei:transcription.tei:p: [printed letterhead with handwritten date:] DIE ZUKUNFT HERAUSGEBER: [–] BERLIN W. 9, den 24/11 1894 MAXIMILIAN HARDEN [–] 27 Köthener Str. [decorated printed rule]

der Artikel über das Streichquartett The article in question is uncertain. Evidently Schenker had written to Harden proposing an article on the string quartet, and presumably also some coverage of Brahms. wird mir sehr willkommen sein. Eben so Strauß, Presumably Johann Strauß the Younger (1825–99). namentlich wenn Sie Lust haben, dabei von Offenbach Jacques Offenbach (1819–80). zu reden, den ich Laie über all Maßen liebe.

Brahms möchte ich Sie bitten, noch zurückzustellen. Es wird so entsetzlich viel gebrahmst. Ist er denn so groß? Mir scheint er aus zweiter Hand, ein Großer in kleiner Zeit. Aber ich verstehe nichts davon.

Auch die jüngste deutsche Musik, einschließend Humperdinck, The German composer Engelbert Humperdinck (1854–1921), who assisted Wagner in preparing the first performance of Parsifal in 1881–82 at Bayreuth, and who was private music tutor to Wagner's son, Siegfried, in 1889–90. (NGDM) ist höchst erwünscht. Ich fand ja nun, daß Sie bei H. voriges Mal nicht glücklich waren, u. ich war über Ihre Vorwürfe See OJ 11/42, [19], October 11, 1894, for Harden's rebuttal of these. betroffen.

Rosenthal See OJ 11/42, [19], October 11, 1894, for Harden's rebuttal of these. und Rubenstein Click on Anton Rubinstein. Since Rubinstein had just died four days earlier, on November 20, 1894, Harden is presumably interested in publishing some correspondence between the two well-known pianists.-Briefe wären höchst erfreulich, bitte, thun Sie das Mögliche dafür!
Es wird mir sehr lieb sein, wenn wir in guter Verbindung bleiben.
Herzlichen Gruß von Ihrem ergebenen [signed:] Harden

[postscript] Die „Zeit“ finde ich arg enttäuschend; alter Kohl, der in der N. Fr. Pr. The Neue freie Presse, the most widely circulated Viennese newspaper, read regularly by Schenker. viel schmackhafter servirt wird.

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten letter from Harden to Schenker, dated November 24, 1894

tei:translation.tei:p: [printed letterhead with handwritten date:] DIE ZUKUNFT EDITOR: [–] BERLIN W. 9, November 24, 1894 MAXIMILIAN HARDEN [–] 27 Köthener Straße [decorated printed rule]
I would welcome the article on the string quartet. Strauß as well, especially if you feel like discussing Offenbach in passing, whom I, as a layman, love beyond all measure.

I’d like to request that you put Brahms on hold. There’s so terribly much Brahmsing going on. Is he really so great? He seems derivative to me—a great man in small times. But I don’t understand anything about this.

Even the most recent German music, including Humperdinck, is extremely pleasant. I just now learned that you were not successful with H[umperdinck] the last time, and I was distraught over your reproaches.
Rosenthal and Rubenstein letters would be exceptionally delightful; please, do your best to get them!
I would very much like it if our relations remain collegial.
Sincere greetings from your faithful [signed:] Harden
[postscript] I find Die Zeit gravely disappointing; stale cabbage that would be served up much more palatably in the Neue Freie Presse|
